channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Carolyn Hax chat: Am I abandoning my family if I move overseas?
item.description: Carolyn Hax chat: Am I abandoning my family if I move overseas?

item.title: Ice, power outage risks grow as D.C. area braces for winter snow storm
item.description: The National Weather Service has placed the area under a winter storm warning from 11 p.m. Saturday through 4 a.m. Monday. The potential for heavy amounts of ice that could lead to power outages has increased, especially south and east of the Beltway.

item.title: ‘He treats us with contempt’: At Davos, Fareed Zakaria encounters a blunt reaction to Trump
item.description: America’s allies may comply for now. But the damage to trust will have consequences, Zakaria writes.

item.title: 10 questions, and don't forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: These 12 cities will be hit hardest by the massive winter storm
item.description: Around 205 million people across the country are under winter weather alerts for snow, ice or extreme cold ahead of the forming tempest.

item.title: Anger in Minnesota. Board of Peace. Jack Smith. Storm forecast. Slavery exhibit. Oscars. How to rebuild hope. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Sharp drops in crime mean the U.S. may now be as safe as it was pre-pandemic
item.description: The country remains in a multiyear trend of falling crime rates in cities nationwide, ushering in a period of relative safety, according to a Washington Post analysis of data from more than 100 police departments. The most striking changes are seen in homicide data.

item.title: TikTok says deal to spin off its U.S. business to non-Chinese investors has been finalized
item.description: The divestiture from TikTok’s Beijing-based former parent company, ByteDance, means that the wildly popular app will continue to operate in the United States and will be owned by a consortium including tech company Oracle and private equity firm Silver Lake.

item.title: National Park Service removes slavery exhibit at Independence Park in Philadelphia
item.description: The exhibit was at the President’s House Site, where George Washington lived as president. The informational panels discussed Washington’s ownership of enslaved people, as well as the broader history of slavery, and included details about their lives. The Park Service has been removing information on historic racism, sexism, LGBTQ+ rights, slavery and climate change since last year as it carries out a Trump executive order.

item.title: House passes DHS funding bill despite Democratic opposition over ICE
item.description: The House narrowly passed $1.2 trillion in government funding, overcoming intense Democratic opposition to funding Immigration and Customs Enforcement as the agency surges operations in Minneapolis and other cities. The Homeland Security funding bill would allocate $64.4 billion to the department, including $10 billion for ICE.

item.title: Walmart found negligent for selling a shotgun used in a suicide
item.description: A federal jury in Maryland awarded millions to the family of Jacob Mace, a store employee who bought the gun on his lunch hour. Mace’s family said managers knew Mace was suicidal and did nothing to ensure that he couldn’t buy a gun from the store.

item.title: FBI is investigating the death of Colts owner Jim Irsay. He had been receiving opioids and ketamine from a recovery doctor.
item.description: A federal grand jury subpoena, reviewed by The Washington Post, shows the agency is seeking records and information relating to Irsay’s death in May, his “substance (illegal and prescription) use” and his “relationship with Dr. Harry Haroutunian,” a prominent addiction specialist based in California.

item.title: Trump sues JPMorgan and its CEO over cutting off his banking access, seeking at least $5 billion in damages
item.description: President Donald Trump alleged that JPMorgan Chase improperly closed his accounts in 2021 and blacklisted him and his family from doing business with the firm.

item.title: Trump budget office orders review of federal funding for 13 Democratic-controlled states and D.C.
item.description: The Trump administration is looking to cut off resources for “sanctuary” jurisdictions that refuse to collaborate with immigration enforcement authorities.

item.title: DOJ says it arrested activists accused of helping organize anti-ICE protest at a Minnesota church that became a flash point
item.description: The protest, which interrupted church services, has drawn widespread condemnation from online right-wing influencers and vows from top Justice Department officials that demonstrators will be prosecuted.

item.title: This obsession has held Iran back for a half-century
item.description: Time and again, idealism untethered from reality has brought ruin to Iran.

item.title: What to know about the high-impact winter storm expected to slam the area this weekend
item.description: The main question is how much snow will fall and whether precipitation will change to an icy mix, coating snow, trees and power lines with a hazardous glaze. Substantial snowfall of at least 4 to 8 inches is likely before any change to ice.

item.title: ‘One of the greatest stories of all time’ in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: ‘Sinners’ breaks record for most Oscar nominations with 16, followed by ‘One Battle After Another.’ See the full list.
item.description: “Frankenstein,” “Hamnet,” “Marty Supreme” and “Sentimental Value” also earned multiple nods in a packed field for the annual awards show.

item.title: Greenland talks. Detainee death. Israeli strike. Trump project. Winter storm. Jimmy Kimmel. Air travel. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Former Uvalde officer acquitted of felony child endangerment charges from 2022 school shooting
item.description: Prosecutors had portrayed the case against Adrian Gonzales as a way to deliver justice and accountability. The defense said he had been unfairly targeted.

item.title: The recent death of an ICE detainee in Texas has been officially deemed a homicide, autopsy confirms
item.description: The report comes the same day a federal judge temporarily barred the deportation of two fellow detainees who said 55-year-old Geraldo Lunas Campos was killed.

item.title: 6 daily habits to slow aging, from a Harvard brain expert
item.description: Neurology professor Rudolph E. Tanzi is the architect of SHIELD, a lifestyle intervention plan for brain health that emphasizes the importance of sleep, handling stress, interaction with others, exercise, learning and diet. Here’s what it looks like in Tanzi’s daily life and some of his tips for continuing to age well.

item.title: Judge blocks government from searching data seized from Washington Post reporter for now
item.description: A federal judge in Virginia issued the ruling hours after The Post demanded in a court filing that federal law enforcement officials return the electronic devices the government seized from a staff reporter’s home last week. The extraordinary search “flouts the First Amendment and ignores federal statutory safeguards for journalists,” The Post told the court.

item.title: Trump says he has reached ‘framework’ of a Greenland deal with NATO secretary general and will reverse tariff threat against Europe
item.description: The announcement, made on President Donald Trump’s social media account, was the latest twist in his effort to seize the Arctic territory from Denmark. The deal is likely to fall far short of the full sovereign possession he was seeking, as NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte is not empowered to negotiate the transfer of territory from one NATO member to another.

item.title: Federal officials launch ICE operation in Maine and begin arrests
item.description: Officials are hoping to avoid a repeat of the widespread resistance that Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s heavy presence has triggered in Minneapolis, according to several officials familiar with the preparations.

item.title: Supreme Court appears likely to allow Lisa Cook to remain on Fed board, a move that would limit Trump’s power over central bank
item.description: President Donald Trump has complained for months that the Fed is not dropping interest rates quickly enough.

item.title: Washington Post demands return of reporter’s materials, writing in court filing that government search flouted First Amendment
item.description: Federal agents executed a search warrant on Jan. 14 at the Virginia home of reporter Hannah Natanson. The seizure “chills speech, cripples reporting, and inflicts irreparable harm,” The Post said in a statement.

item.title: A whopper storm could soon engulf a 2,000-mile stretch of the U.S. with snow and ice this weekend. Here’s what to know.
item.description: Significant snow and ice, as well as frigid temperatures, will affect more than 200 million people across the country.

item.title: ‘An icon’ in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: Trump asks for ‘immediate negotiations’ to acquire Greenland, says he does not intend to use force to gain territory
item.description: President Donald Trump asserted during his remarks at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, that Greenland is “actually part of North America” and is therefore “a core national security interest of the United States of America.”

item.title: Trump opens speech at Davos touting U.S. economy. Follow our live coverage.
item.description: President Donald Trump’s remarks to the annual gathering of executives, politicians and other prominent figures from around the world comes as European leaders try to de-escalate tensions with the United States over the president’s plan to acquire Greenland.

item.title: Davos disputes. Trump monologue. Jan. 6 pardons. DOGE and data. ICE in Minneapolis. Winter storm. Brain aging. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Lindsey Halligan out as U.S. attorney following pressure from judges
item.description: One federal judge in Virginia sought applications for her replacement. Another called her use of the U.S. attorney title a “charade."

item.title: An earlier alert incorrectly concluded a court filing had said a DOGE member fulfilled an agreement to share Social Security data to overturn elections
item.description: The Justice Department submitted a court filing Friday in an ongoing case saying that the Social Security Administration had discovered a secret agreement between a DOGE employee and an unidentified political advocacy group. The agreement called for sharing Social Security data with the aim of overturning election results in certain states, according to the filing. An earlier alert failed to acknowledge, the agency learned of the agreement in November, according to the court filing, but had “not yet seen evidence that SSA data were shared with the advocacy group.”

item.title: U.S. DOGE Service members shared sensitive Social Security data with the aim of overturning election results, court filing shows
item.description: The Trump administration has acknowledged for the first time in a court filing that members of DOGE accessed and shared the data without the awareness of agency officials.

item.title: Carlos Beltrán elected to National Baseball Hall of Fame despite sign-stealing scandal. Andruw Jones also heads to Cooperstown.
item.description: Beltrán was voted in by baseball writers despite his reputation as a ringleader of Houston’s infamous scheme in 2017.

item.title: Virginia Democrats target military college’s funding after anti-DEI push, a move that could jeopardize its state-funded status
item.description: A resolution filed Tuesday would, if approved, establish a task force with broad authority to investigate whether Virginia Military Institute has done enough to root out racism and sexism at the school.

item.title: Pentagon plans to cut U.S. participation in some NATO advisory groups in latest move to scale back investment in Europe’s defense
item.description: The move has been under consideration for months, according to two U.S. officials, one of whom said it is unrelated to President Donald Trump’s escalating threats to seize the Danish territory of Greenland.

item.title: Judge seeks replacement of Trump loyalist Halligan as interim U.S. attorney in Virginia, escalating standoff with Justice Dept.
item.description: In a pair of extraordinary moves, two federal judges issued court orders saying they intend to remove Lindsey Halligan at the helm of the key U.S. attorney’s office and threatening disciplinary sanctions for any government lawyer who continues to refer to her as U.S. attorney in legal filings. An out-of-district judge had ruled in November that the Trump administration used an unlawful maneuver to install her.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Stepchild’s mom has much lower income and ‘expects’ not to pay
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Stepchild’s mom has much lower income and ‘expects’ not to pay

item.title: Seeking the ideal protein? You’re probably already eating it.
item.description: Humans need (some) protein, of course. But an entire multibillion-dollar industry has sprung up to sell us a lot more of something we don’t need. Our columnist’s journey through the scientific literature and decades of research led to one conclusion: We’re overthinking this.

item.title: A proposed Homeland Security rule could empty U.S. stadium seats
item.description: Asking visitors from allied countries to submit social media data could curb World Cup tourism.

item.title: A prize is the topic of today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Greenland. Gun regulations. ICE protest. MLK march. Drought maps. College football. ‘House burping.’ Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Indiana fights off Miami, caps perfect season with College Football Playoff national championship
item.description: The Hoosiers were among the least successful programs in major college football for generations. Now they are an undefeated national champion.

item.title: She helped him flee a rally, then learned he was a right-wing provocateur
item.description: Jake Lang, a pardoned Jan. 6 rioter, jumped into a stranger’s car after he was driven from his anti-immigrant march in Minneapolis by a large counterprotest.

item.title: Justice Department considering rollback of gun regulations, seeking to bolster support from Second Amendment advocates
item.description: The administration seeks to placate gun-rights groups that have criticized Attorney General Pam Bondi. Some of the changes are expected to ease restrictions on the private sale of guns and loosen regulations around shipping firearms.

item.title: Public health groups file lawsuit to reverse RFK Jr.’s new vaccine guidance for children
item.description: Several health organizations are suing to overturn a decision from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, arguing that Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and others failed to consider how the policy would endanger families and burden the health care system.

item.title: How to dress better with the 3-3-3 rule and 6 other numerical guides
item.description: Experts break down all those viral fashion recommendations — what works, what to tweak and one to avoid.
